key_risks: Environmental impact of energy-intensive manufacturing processes
Health and safety concerns related to fiber exposure during installation
Regulatory and market risks tied to building codes and energy efficiency standards
Supply chain dependencies on raw materials like basalt rock and recycled slag
controversies: Historical concerns about potential respiratory risks from fiber exposure
Challenges in achieving carbon neutrality despite sustainability commitments
environmental_issues: Significant Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions
Dependence on fossil fuels for high-temperature melting processes
social_issues: Potential health risks for workers and installers from fiber exposure
Market trust issues due to lingering perceptions of health risks
governance_issues: None identified; strong corporate governance and ethical practices noted

sources.title: ROCKWOOL Technical Insulation - A net carbon negative impact

sources.title: Rockwool Insulation and Environmental Responsibility
sources.snippet: Rockwool can be recycled back into new insulation products. Currently, up to 25% recycled Rockwool content is used in new materials. Embodied carbon and energy: It has a high embodied carbon footprint from energy-intensive manufacturing involving greenhouse gas emissions. Rockwool's embodied carbon is among the lowest for insulations.
